NOTES  
 
 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government ends on 31 December.  
(ii)       In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by M. Mitra, Agriculture, Environment, and Natural Resources 
Division, Mekong Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) is the outcome of ongoing efforts in the Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) to bring about gender equity in access to resources and 
participation in economic development.1 The Government requested the TA during a workshop 
to discuss potential areas TA using poverty funds.2 The Government of the Lao PDR is engaged 
in reforming land administration and titling.3 There are emerging concerns related to gender 
equity in the ongoing process of planning and allocation of land, forest, and water resources. 
The Lao PDR is signatory to the Beijing Platform for Action, which highlights the importance of 
gender equality in the control of, and access to, productive resources. The Lao PDR ratified the 
Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1981. The 
Constitution provides for equal rights of women to land. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) is 
responsible for central land management, registration, issuance land titles, and leasing land. 
The Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF) is responsible for agriculture and forestland.4 
The provincial agriculture and forestry offices (PAFOs) and district agriculture and forestry 
offices (DAFOs) are responsible for land-use planning and land allocation for agricultural and 
forestlands. Implementation of the land-related laws is dispersed through a number of agencies, 
and the lack of capacity and coordination on issues of ethnicity, gender, and culture can lead to 
negative  impacts  on  ethnic  minority  communities,  particularly  on  women.  The  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) has held discussions with the Government, civil society, and mass 
organizations, to determine the need for a comprehensive study of the extent and impacts of 
gender inequality in relation to access and control over land, forests and water resources, 
among ethnic minorities in the Nam Ngum Basin. In November 2003 a fact-finding mission held 
discussions  with  MOF,  MAF,  Lao  Women’s  Union  (LWU),  provincial  governments, 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and local communities, to seek concurrence on the TA’s 
goal and purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and 
terms of reference  The TA Framework is attached in Appendix 1.5  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Lao PDR is among the poorest countries in the Greater Mekong Subregion, with a 
national poverty level of 36% (1998). Rural poverty is high, with 50–74% of the population below 
the poverty line in the northern and mountain areas. Poverty is most pronounced among rural 
populations, especially ethnic minorities. During the 2001 Participatory Poverty Assessment 
(PPA), ethnic minorities specifically identified factors leading to poverty: government policies 
related to shifting cultivation; land-use planning and land allocation; relocation programs; and 
lack of equitable access to land, forest, and water resources.6  
 
3.  Women in the Lao PDR are extremely active in the economy and primarily responsible

in July 2003. 
2  A workshop was organized at the Lao Resident Mission in May 2003, during which the Government requested TAs 
for gender mainstreaming, including the above TA. 
3  The  World  Bank-assisted  Lao  PDR  Land-Titling  Project  has  been  in  operation  for  5  years,  and  is  being 
implemented by the Department of Land Management on behalf of MOF. 
4  The Department of Land and Housing Management is the core national agency responsible for the design and 
implementation of land management and administration programs. The mandate as defined by the Prime Minister's 
Office Decree 104, 6 July 1993, is to carry out, under the direction of the Land Re-Management Committee, the 
design and supervision of national land registration and titling programs through the offices of provincial services. 
The district land officer supported by the village headman (nai baan) provides the documentation, including tax 
certification and proof of ownership, together with the required witnesses and documentation, to the provincial 
office, which certifies and signs the documentation to the land.  
5  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 14 October 2003. 
6  ADB. 2001. Participatory Poverty Assessment: Lao People’s Democratic Republic. Manila.

2 
for meeting their households’ food requirements, health, and well-being. Gender gaps exist in 
several areas and are wider among northern ethnic minorities. Maternal mortality rates among 
ethnic minorities are higher than national levels, at 540 per 100,000 live births. Only two minority 
cultures, the Pray in Xaygnabouri and the Sou’ in Attapeu, are matrilineal; the rest either have 
bilateral  or  patrilineal  lines  of  inheritance.  Groups  such  as  the  Hmong  and  Khmu  do  not 
recognize  women’s  rights  to  own  property  except  under  specific  circumstances.  All  ethnic 
minority  cultures  assign  women  heavier  workloads  than  men  for  food  production,  income 
generation,  domestic  work,  and  maintenance  of  cultural  traditions.  While  customary  laws 
prohibit  them  from  inheriting  land  (depending  upon  the  culture  and  circumstances),  ethnic 
minority women living in traditional communities, do have access to land for food and livestock 
production, and collection of forest produce.  
 
4.  National laws, policies, and programs are increasingly impacting upon the capacity of 
ethnic minority women to meet their households’ need for food security, minimum nonfood 
requirements, and requirements of cultural traditions.7 Recent researches by LWU found that 
during land registration, women lost out, by not having their names included in a variety of of 
land related documents. Researches from the Land-Titling Project and the Lao Swedish Upland 
Agriculture and Forestry Research Program emphasize the need for greater attention to gender 
issues in nonethnic Lao areas.  
 
5.  Several laws and decrees determine land use planning and allocation.8 Land Decree 99 
(1992) grants long-term land-use rights to Lao citizens. Such rights can be inherited, traded, 
leased, or sold. Land-use titles may be granted to the land users. While the Constitution and the 
decree recognize women’s rights to hold land, the implementation regulations9 often do not. 
Closely linked to land rights are rights to forest and water resources. Decrees10 have been 
passed to allocate land for forestry, plantation, and pastures to communities and individuals.11 
As a result of Article 20 of the Forestry Law, ethnic minority farmers cannot use forest fallow 
older than 4 years, which means they can be allocated a maximum of four parcels of agricultural 
land.12 This causes soil degradation, declining rice yields, and increasing weed encroachment. 
Water rights and decision making related to water management derive from land-use rights. 
Even as the Lao PDR adopts community-managed irrigation systems, ethnic minority women 
                                                 
7  Lao women are less literate than men (59.0% compared to 81.7%), and this gap is much larger for ethnic 
minorities. Similar gaps exist in schooling, enrolment, and completion levels. (ADB. 2001. Participatory Poverty 
Assessment: Lao People’s Democratic Republic. Manila.)  
8 The Constitution, promulgated in 1991, affirms the rights of individuals to use the land. The Fifth Party Congress 
(March 1991) identified the need to accelerate land registration and issue land title certificates. Management and 
administration policies are reflected in the decrees promulgated by the Government, Property Law (1990), Land 
Decree (99 Prime Minister [PM]), Land Tax Decree (50 PM), Document Registration Decree (52 PM), and Forest 
Management and Land-Use Decree (169 PM). A recent decree (186 PM) covers the allocation of forestlands with 
reference to allocation of lands to plantation forestry.  
9 The only specific mention of gender with respect to land titles, is in the Constitution, which states that the names of 
husband  and  wife  should  be  recorded  in  the  Land  Register  Book.  The  lack  of  gender  sensitivity  in  the 
implementation regulations was noted in the report of the Lao Consulting Group on the Existing Land Tenure and 
Forest Lands Study.  
10 Decree 169 divided forestland into five categories: production, protection, conservation, village, and degraded. 
Decree 186 allows the state to allocate forestland for tree plantation and forest protection. In 1994 the National 
Assembly recognized Decree 169 as the forestry law, legalizing State control over forests. This law recognizes 
private rights over forests and ignores common property resources and communal rights to forest areas.   
11 Decree 169 formalizes village rights to forest areas. Decision 0054/MAF defines and recognizes customary rights 
in forest and forestland. Article 4 states that these rights may be exercised freely within the limits of the law. 
However, some practices such as swiddens may be limited, which may reduce ethnic minorities’ rice and livestock 
production. Registration of parcels of village forest in the name of the State will diminish ethnic minorities’ access to 
resources.  
12  Lao Consulting Group. 2002. Existing Land Tenure and Forest Lands Study, Land Titling Project. Laos.

3 
hardly participate in community-based water management groups.13  
 
6.    The Government has stressed the importance of ADB providing TA for mainstreaming 
gender in agriculture, which is a priority sector for poverty reduction. As a first step, trends and 
patterns of gender differentiation in access to, and control over, productive resources along 
ethnic lines should be understood in-depth, and a strategy formulated to address these trends 
and  patterns.  The  counterpart  project,  Nam  Ngum  Basin  Development  Project,  is  being 
implemented in Xieng Khouang Province, Xaysamboun Special Zone, and Vientiane Province 
and municipality. These provinces have a large number of small and big ethnic minorities with a 
variety of cultures and traditional systems.14 The TA will concentrate on the extent and impacts 
of gender inequality among these communities, in relation to land and natural resources for 
livelihood and food security. Lessons learned will be upscaled in other ADB-assisted projects in 
the Lao PDR. 
 
III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
   
A.  Purpose and Output 
7.    The Project’s goal is to identify ways to reduce poverty and improve gender equity 
among  ethnic  minorities  living  in  the  Nam  Ngum  Basin.  The  purposes  are  to  (i)  increase 
awareness within government agencies and communities, of the extent and impacts on poverty, 
of prevalent gender inequality in access to land, forest, and water resources, among ethnic 
minority communities in the Nam Ngum Basin; (ii) to design solutions to address the issues of 
gender inequality and poverty among these communities, and (iii) to institutionalize gender 
responsive programs within government agencies, that can help to address the issues of gender 
inequality and poverty.  
 
8.    The scope of the Project includes the following: (i) in the first phase, an ethnographic 
study of gender issues, primarily in terms of ethnic minorities’ rights and access to land and 
related issues of access to forest and water resources; and (ii) in the second phase, preparation 
and  implementation  of a  detailed strategy  to improve  gender  outcomes  in  the  counterpart 
project. The ethnographic study to be done in the first phase will address the following: (i) 
gender patterns of resource allocation, management, and rights under customary laws of ethnic 
minority communities living in the Nam Ngum Basin; (ii) the impacts on women’s rights, of state 
laws and policies of relocation, stabilization of shifting cultivation, land-use planning and land 
allocation, forest demarcation, water resource allocation and management, (iii) analysis of the 
factors  responsible  for  gender  gaps  in  delivery  of  government  services  and  programs, 
particularly to ethnic minority women; and (iv) recommendations to close these gaps.  
 
9.    The outputs will include (i) improved policy environment on gender equity in access to 
resources  (ii)  increased  awareness  among  government  agencies  and  ethnic  minority 
communities regarding the links between gender inequality and poverty, and increased support 
for gender equity in access to and control over such resources, (iii) implementation of gender 
responsive policies and measures designed to improve access of ethnic minority women and 
girls to land, forest and water resources, and (iv) a strategy to institutionalize such policies and 
measures through the Nam Ngum Basin Development Sector Project, which is the counterpart 
project for the TA. Success indicators include (i) completion of research and documentation; (ii) 
rural  women’s  participation  in  community-based  organizations  for  natural  resource 
                                                 
13 Since the membership of such groups has to do with access to irrigable lands, the absence of ethnic minorities 
shows their lack of access to such resources. 
14 Refer to ADB. 2001. Participatory Poverty Assessment: Lao People’s Democratic Republic. Manila.

4 
management; (iii) workshops held with stakeholder participation; (iv) improved gender capacity 
and coordination among government agencies; (v) translation of key project outputs into local 
languages, and dissemination of these outputs through local workshops and mass organizations 
and  counterpart  project  agencies;  (vi)  positive  results  of  gender-sensitive  poverty  impact 
assessment; (vii) sensitization of ADB staff through dissemination of key outputs; and (viii) 
incorporation of lessons learned into future ADB operations in the developing member countries 
and in the sector.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.   The TA will cover districts with more than 50% ethnic minority population and high levels 
of poverty. The TA will be implemented in two phases. First, an ethnographic study will be 
carried out with the findings of the 2001 PPA as the starting point.15 While it is a rich source of 
information on experiences of poverty of different cultural groups and their priorities, the PPA 
does not specifically address gender impacts of laws and policies related to land and forests 
with regard to women’s rights and livelihoods. The TA will address specific gender issues. It will 
review laws, policies, and secondary materials, particularly writings of anthropologists such as 
Georges Condominas, James Chamberlain,16 and others; and studies from Lao sources such 
as the Land-Titling Project, Lao Swedish Upland Agriculture and Forestry Research Project, 
National  Growth  and  Poverty  Eradication  Strategy,  Lao  Women’s  Union  (LWU),  Gender 
Resource Information and Development (GRID), ADB-assisted projects, among others.  
 
11.   Following the review of materials, a Project Inception report will be prepared which will 
summarize the present situation and indicate research issues and methodology. Participatory 
field research will be carried out in at least three sites per province, in the subproject areas of 
the counterpart project.17 Participatory research sites will be selected on the basis of (i) ethnic 
minority population, (ii) poverty level, and (iii) presence of relocated communities.18 A few 
additional sites—traditional minority settlements, as well as mixed settlements where several 
groups  live  side  by  side—will  be  selected  to  study  land-use  planning  and  land  allocation 
processes and provide the basis for case studies.  
 
12.   Research methodology will consist of participant observation by teams staying in the 
sites; village meetings; focus group discussions with men and women, village leaders, and staff 
of land-use planning and land allocation agencies; key informant interviews; local workshops 
with  village  participants  and  mass  organizations;  district  and  provincial  workshops;  and 
triangulation of findings. Research teams will be drawn from a local research or academic 
institution, DAFO and LWU staff at the district level, and ethnic minority women and men from 
the selected villages. Each research team will have at least two women. The teams will be 
trained in gender-sensitive participatory research. Local and provincial workshops will be used 
to feed data back to the participants to confirm findings and recommendations. In the second 
phase, the activities will be (i) preparation of a detailed strategy to improve capacity of ethnic 
minority women, communities, and MAF and other government agencies; and training and

5 
awareness-raising methodologies; (ii) dissemination of key outputs to the Government, NGOs, 
and other relevant stakeholders through workshops; (iii) dissemination to ADB staff by putting 
the key project results on ADB’s web site and in-house seminars; (iv) translation of key outputs 
into local languages; (v) monitoring of gender and development impacts under the counterpart 
project; and (vi) incorporation of the study’s recommendations and of lessons learned from the 
capacity-building component into the midterm review of the counterpart loan and into designs of 
future ADB and other projects in the sector in the Lao PDR.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.   The total cost of the TA is estimated at $295,000 equivalent, of which $ 162,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $133,000 equivalent is the local currency cost. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $162,000, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and $88,000 
equivalent of the local currency costs. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Poverty 
Reduction Cooperation Fund and administered by ADB. The Government will bear the balance 
of  local  currency  costs,  amounting  to  $45,000  equivalent,  through  the  provision  of  office 
accommodation, administrative support, staff remuneration, and staff per diems. Cost estimates 
and financing arrangements are provided in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.   MAF will be the project executing agency. Implementing agencies will include DAFOs, 
PAFOs, and provincial units of LWU and GRID in the selected provinces. The Project steering 
committee  will consist of MAF,  Office of the National Project Manager, Nam Ngum Basin 
Development Sector Project (ONPM), LWU, Water Resources Coordination Center, PAFOs and 
DAFOs,  and  representatives  of  LWU  and  GRID  in  the  selected  provinces.  The  steering 
committee will meet once every 6 months to discuss issues and outcomes of the Project and 
take stock of progress. The Project will be implemented over 24 months, from June 2004 to May 
2006. Milestones will comprise (i) an inception meeting, (month 1); (ii) desk review of existing 
data and preparation of inception report (month 2); (iii) site selection and participatory research 
(within 6 months); (iv) local, provincial, and national workshops (months 11-13) (v) preparation 
of interim report for submission to ADB (month 13-14); (vi) implementation of strategy for 
capacity building of government agencies, communities (within months 14-24); (vi) draft final 
report for submission to ADB (months16-17) and (vi) final report (month 22), ADB comments to 
be incorporated and revised report to be submitted to ADB (month 24), .  
   
15.  An international consultant (Team Leader)—a social anthropologist/lawyer with gender 
expertise and experience in the sector—will be recruited for 5 person-months, along with a 
domestic consultant—sociologist/gender specialist—recruited for 12 person-months, to carry out 
the study in collaboration with local Lao institutions. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory 
to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 to the Government 
of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic to be financed on a grant basis by the Poverty 
Reduction Cooperation Fund for the Study of Gender Inequality in Women’s Access to Land, 
Forests, and Water, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   International Consultant (5 person-months) 
 
1.  The  international  consultant  (team  leader)  will  have  a  master’s  degree  in  social 
anthropology or law from a reputed university, and at least 5-10 years working experience in the 
field of gender, property rights, livelihood, and poverty reduction in the Mekong region. The 
consultant will be familiar with the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) and have 
significant publications in her or his field. A working knowledge of the Lao language will be 
desirable. As team leader she or he will be responsible for overall management of the technical 
assistance Project, preparation of the required reports, and timely delivery of Project outputs. 
The consultant will have the following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  In agreement with the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF), Office of the 
National Project Management (ONPM), provincial Lao Women’s Union (LWU), 
provincial  agriculture  and  forestry  office  (PAFO)  and  district  agriculture  and 
forestry office (DAFO), (a) select study sites in Vientiane, Xaysamboun, and 
Xieng  Khouang  provinces,  with  high  poverty  levels  and  at  least  50%  ethnic 
minority  population;  (b)  prepare  a  study  design,  including  the  participatory 
methodology to be used; (c) provide training to PAFO, DAFO, and provincial 
LWU staff on the study’s methodology and approach; (d) in association with the 
domestic consultant and LWU staff, collect relevant data from ethnic minority 
communities, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), government agencies, and 
international agencies; (e) analyze the data; (f) conduct workshops and training 
programs, and communicate the TA design, findings, and recommendations to all 
stakeholders; (g) submit inception, interim, draft final and final reports to the 
steering committee and to Asian Development Bank, (ADB) . 
(ii)  Prepare a report on women’s access to land, forests, and water resources in the 
Lao  PDR.  The  team  leader  will  (a)  review  relevant  secondary  materials, 
including, among others, reports arising out of the World Bank-assisted Land-
Titling  Project,  Lao  Swedish  Forestry  Project,  National  Poverty  Eradication 
Program,  ADB-assisted  projects,  the  United  Nations’  Development  Program 
(UNDP), Lao Women’s Union (LWU), and Gender Resource Information and 
Development  (GRID) project, all available relevant research documents, (b) 
prepare a design for the study, including methodology, (c) based on the above, 
prepare and submit the inception report (d) supervise the implementation of the 
participatory  field  research,  prepare  and  submit  interim  report  (e)  prepare  a 
detailed strategy to improve gender awareness and equity and build capacity, 
among government agencies and communities;  (f) prepare the draft final TA 
report based on the above, analyzing women’s property rights under different 
pieces of legislation, customary rights, and practices, prevalent among different 
ethnic minority communities; impacts of relocation programs and programs to 
control shifting cultivation, on women’s livelihoods, their access to resources, 
poverty levels, and living standards; trends in women’s rights, and levels of 
access to resources, as well as women’s livelihoods; women’s social status; 
levels of women’s representation in community decision making; capacity among 
government  agencies,  particularly  Department  of  Land  and  Housing 
Management (DOLHM), provincial agriculture and poverty office (PAFO), district 
agriculture and forestry office (DAFO), and ONPM, to address gender issues; 
and (g) undertake pilot training workshops with government agencies under the 
counterpart project.

(iii)  In  implementing  the  TA  and  finalizing  the  TA  report,  review  (a)  secondary 
materials on gender, poverty, and ethnic minority customary laws and practices, 
with particular reference to the Project area; (b) patterns of distribution of land, 
forests, and water resources, and their management; (c) relocation programs and 
their impacts; (d) land-use planning and its impacts on distribution, management 
of  resources,  and  benefits  arising  thereof;  (e)  laws,  policies,  projects,  and 
programs governing distribution of resources and security of tenure; (f) external 
agency-assisted projects and their impacts; (g) research conducted by LWU in 
provinces on women’s access to resources; and (h) NGO activities in the project 
area. 
(iv)  In  implementing  the  TA,  pay  particular  attention  to  gender-responsive 
participatory methodologies. In setting out the methodology and training of LWU 
and government staff, the team leader will emphasize the need to enable ethnic 
minority communities, particularly women, to participate in discussions and put 
across their viewpoints. The team leader will ensure that during participatory rural 
appraisals, a relaxed and flexible environment is created that will enable the 
sharing of information and experiences, views, and concerns. Women will be 
separately contacted by the team, and separate meetings will be held to enable 
them to speak and participate freely. The views of ethnic minority women will be 
particularly sought on (a) women’s customary rights to resources, including land, 
livestock, forest, and water; (b) distribution of resources; (c) women’s roles and 
responsibilities in the community; (d) effects of relocation programs on ethnic 
minority communities, particularly on women’s work and livelihoods, household 
food  security,  poverty  and  its  causes,  nature,  impacts;  (e)  impacts  of  land 
registration  on  women;  (f)  women’s  participation  in  community  resource 
allocation and management decisions; and (g) measures for women to gain 
greater rights of access and control over productive resources such as land, 
livestock, forests, and water resources. After data collection, the team leader will 
work closely with the domestic consultant to analyze the data. Research findings 
should be triangulated with the ethnic minority communities. The team leader will 
ensure that all stakeholders, including central, provincial and district agencies, 
LWU staff, communities, NGOs, and donors are fully involved. They should be 
enabled to participate in the confirmation of the research outputs and enabled to 
provide feedback to strengthen the TA reports. After the completion of the draft 
report, the team leader will help organize and participate in a pilot workshop to 
train government agencies.  
(v)  Form linkages between the TA and ongoing development programs and policies. 
The team leader will consistently link the research and fieldwork with ongoing 
development  activities  and  policy  analysis,  with  particular  relevance  to  land 
administration and titling, land reforms, land-use planning and land allocation, 
relocation programs, and control of shifting cultivation, among others. Links will 
also be established with ongoing and new initiatives on gender and development, 
especially those related to data collection and dissemination, policymaking to 
promote women’s access to resources, decision making, and capacity building to 
address gender issues.  
 
2.   The consultant will finalize technical assistance outputs as follows. In preparing the TA 
report, the team leader will pay particular attention to the following: (i) methodology; (ii) analysis 
of  the  population  distribution  in  the  study  area,  including  ethnic  minority  communities;  (iii) 
poverty among ethnic minority communities, in particular among ethnic minority women; (iv) 
customary laws and practices among ethnic minority communities, with particular reference to

B.   Domestic Consultant (12 person-months) 
 
3.  The consultant will be a sociologist specializing in gender. She or he should have done 
research on gender, poverty, and land rights in the Lao PDR. The consultant should have 
knowledge and experience of working among ethnic minority communities. Knowledge of ethnic 
minority languages will be useful. She or he will collect, review, and analyze data; participate in 
workshops and meetings; and help the team leader prepare TA outputs. She or he will
